newsitem.title: HONG KONG: China tightens border controls with Macau - papers.
newsitem.headline: China tightens border controls with Macau - papers.

text.p: China has tightened security on the border with Macau in an effort to help the Portuguese-run territory crack down on a gang-related crime wave, Macau's Chinese-language newspapers reported on Wednesday.

The stricter controls were meant to "fight illegal immigration and stop the entry and exit of suspected criminals," the Va Kio daily quoted Chinese border inspection office spokesman Huang Yan-quan as saying.
Huang said the office would also step up vetting of illegal immigrants deported from neighbouring Macau in an effort to identify criminals but gave no further details.
So-called "snakeheads" charge about 5,000 yuan ($600) a head to spirit Chinese nationals into Macau, a Portuguese outpost for more than 400 years.
A wave of shootings, bombings and arson attacks blamed on a turf war between members of rival Chinese criminal organisations known as "triad societies" has rocked once-sleepy Macau in recent months.
Police suspect many of the shootings were carried out by imported mainland hitmen.
Macau, which reverts to China in 1999, deported 6,875 illegal immigrants to China last year, an increase of 4.3 percent on 1995 levels, government statistics show.
The Macau peninsula is located on the southern delta of the Pearl River and shares a narrow 240 metre (yard) land border with China
But the surrounding bays separating Macau from the southern Chinese region of Zhuhai are shallow and easy to navigate.
